fileDesc.extent: Approx. 6 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 1 1-bit group-IV TIFF page image.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: Simplex cibus multiplici est anteponendus ; Impura corpora quò plus nutries, eò magis lædes

notesStmt.note: Contains Latin verses related to theses at Cambridge University.
Imprint torn, publisher suggested by STC (2nd ed.).
Imperfect: torn, with some loss of print.
Reproduction of original in the Cambridge University Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2007-08 Apex CoVantageKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2007-09 Elspeth HealeyText and markup reviewed and edited

lg.l: NOn eſt, vt chordis, non eſt concentus in eſca
Multiplici, non eſt cur variare velis.
Quàm grauis eſt patriae miſerandae cauſa ruinae,
Cùm plebs, cùm patres ſeditione ſtrepunt:
Tam grauis eſt ſtomacho diſcordia cauſa pericli,
Cùm leue cùm durum conſociare paras.
Si varium Bacchum, per ſe coeleſtia dona,
Exhauris, ſenſus ebrietate grauas:
Sic pondus pigros premit intolerabile ventres,
Vnà diſſimiles inijciendo dapes.

Digeritur facilis, grauior p • treſcit: vtér
que
Noxius, hic vſtus, crudior ille manet.
Fama refert in equo, quem credula Troia recepit,
Vnanimes tutò delituiſſe duces:
Haud tamen infenſam potuit cum coniuge miti,
Socrate, Xantippen vna tenere domus.
Sic ſi quis menſas epulis inſtruxerit vnis,

Ille ſalutiferas conficit abſ
que malo:
At qui magnifico celebrat conuiuia luxu,
In ſtomacho turbas vel meliore ciet.

Nam fit delicijs rudis indigeſtá
que moles,

Vel quòd edis ſupra ſuauia quae
que modum:
Vel quòd (vt imponat finem moderatio iuſtum)
Aduerſi ſucci bella timenda gerunt,
Quos, ſeu concretam varijs de gentibus vrbem,
Maximus eſt firma pace ligare labor.
Vt ſine morte potens tripli ••• ſuperare Chimaeram,
Vix vnus Glauci filius ipſe poteſt:
Sic alimenta graui vincet contraria damno,
Vincere ſi calidi vis generoſa valet.
Vita, valetudo, vires diſcrimine tanto,
Neſcio quod metuunt exitiale malum.
Anne bonus patina ſimul accumulabit eadem
Plurima quae multùm ſunt aliena, coquus?
•… empe piper, p •… ſcem, vituli cum carne ferinam,
Pernam, perdic es, zinziber, oua, nuces?
Confuſè patina ſeruum miſcere pu 〈…〉
Ac aluo dominum non pudet iſta ſuum?
Non pudor eſt. Mos eſt. Tamen iſta timere neceſſe eſt,
Omnibus eſt gladijs plùs metue •… da gula.
• acetenim natura dolet, cadit, aeſtuat, alget,
Haeret, & in triuio, qua queat ire, ſtupet.
Vt cui plura ſimul peragenda negotia reſtant,
Neſcit quod primùm perficiatur opus
Ac alternatim poterat quae ſingula, linquit
Cuncta ſimul. Mu •… um vis ſociata iuuat,

•… ed diſtracta vijs varij •… intentá
que rebus
Pluribus eſt 〈◊…〉 ſolet •••… minor.
〈…〉 integra, quotquot
〈…〉 liciore cibo.

div.head: Impura corpora quò plus nutries, eò magis laedes.

lg.l: NEſcio quae multos decepit opinio, multo
Credunt ſe morbos pellere poſſe cibo.

Quae poſſunt igitur bellaria cun
que parari,
Obtrudunt, ſanguis cui vitiatus ineſt.
Quin bibis, & comedis? Quin te, chariſſime, ſeruas?
Hoc vnum quaſi ſit, multa vorare ſatis.
Omnibus eſt aliquid, ne vis cadat omnis, edendum:
Sed tamen impuris copia ſumpta nocet.
Materiémne vides proprijs temerare venenis
Hanc illam, veterem contaminare nouam?
Sic mellita magis reddit magis acria bilis,
Quicquid edit ſerpens, id citò virus erit.
Vberiore ſeges, quo perniciôſior omnis
Quàm bona, ſi nutris fertilitate viget:
Pingue minùs rapidis oleum ſuperadde caminis,
Vulcani multò ſaeuior ira furit:
Da nummos homini, qui multa recondidit, auri
Incipiet magis hunc vrere ſacra fames:
Et licèt ad mentum medio ſit in amne, quis vnquàm
Hydrops extinguet plura bibendo ſitim?
Adde quòd humor iners contactu polluit ipſo,
Haud ſecùs ac dulces inficit aequor aquas.
Peiorémne putas meliori cedere? Vires
Auget, & appoſitum ſub ditione tenet.
Inſtar & eſt dominae, quae fraude tyrannide parta
Omnia deprauans imperioſa regit.

Cúm
que cibus primùm deſcendit in intima gratus
Hunc rapit, hunc ſubigit degenerare ſtatim.
Vt qui ſaxificae ſpectabant ora Meduſae,
Attoniti miris diriguere modis:

Vertit vt in fuluum diuéſ
que miſér
que metallum,
Quae manibus potuit tangere cuncta Midas:
Cogitur vt miſto lac & coaleſcit aceto:
Laedit vt inſipido vappa ſapore merum:

Haud ſecùs humorem, quae cun
que receperis intùs
Pabula, corruptum qui dominatur, alunt.

Nàm
que valent pauci multos ſuperare, viritim
Obuius hic illo ſi pereunte, venit.

Cúm
que minutatim caeca conduntur in aluo
Singula, vincendi copia nulla datur.

Flumine vaſa lauas, (laudo quo
que ) nám
que liquores
Mutabit ſuaues inueteratus odor.
Exoneranda malo ſucco ſunt viſcera, tandem
Audebis tutò ſuppeditare nouum.
Euacuare times? Licet attenuare coquendo,
Dum ratio cupidas abſtinet ore manus:

Dúm
que ſalutaris Medicina refrigerat aeſtum,
Ne mala putreſcant feruidiora ſitu.

l.hi: Quantò igitur magis impuris alimenta miniſtras
